ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A basic understanding of intro linguistics and historical linguistics
This course covers the core topics in historical linguistics and explores how language has evolved and the common pathways that have led to modern languages.
This class offered a broad overview of processes in historical linguistics and how linguists use modern languages to learn about older forms of these languages.
Data interpretation techniques for hist. linguistics data, common themes in language evolution, very comprehensive overview of pathways of change for different linguistic items

I got a thorough understanding on the topics and methods used in historical linguistic analysis, and left the course with a solid skillset that would allow me to enter research in the field even if I have never interacted with linguistics before
How languages change and interact in terms of semantic, sound, and syntactic change.

How to analyze related languages and determine common ancestors
An understanding of how languages change over time, phonologically, semantically, and syntactically
I better understand the way languages are interrelated.
Interesting material about languages and their development.
I came to think about the sounds we make in words, and how they have changed to their current form. Now I think in a whole new way about how I and others speak.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The in class exercises are very helpful since the lectures cover only the theoretical side of a given topic.

While the lectures were often quite long, I often felt that they lacked information that would have been helpful for the problem sets. They offered lots of linguistic examples, but did not necessarily explain how to do the problems that we were assigned.

Strenghts: the homeworks are engaging and follow from the material, the weekly discussions were extremely helpful

Cons: I think the lectures could be a bit more organized sometimes. Maybe it was the slide structure, but I would often lose track about what the example that was being discussed was suposed to show, or whehter concept X was a particular case of the previous concept or a completely separate one. This was often clarified with help of the textbook

Strengths: very consistent class, clear feedback, effective use of examples in class, variety of resources provided (particularly practice quizzes!)
Weaknesses: some topics are covered more extensively than others, some resources not clearly brought to light
I liked that the sections were live because it was much more engaging but that lectures were recorded to allow for some flexibility.
I thought it was a good course, though obviously it had to change in response to covid. I really found the material fascinating, and thought it was conveyed well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course had both live discussions and recorded lectures. This often resulted in much more than the allocated 2hrs30 per week in material. This is not an acceptable way to teach during the pandemic as it simply takes advantage of the situation to give the students more work.
The pre-recorded lectures with weekly discussios worked perfectly with COVID. The frequent homeworks also helped keep me engaged.

Succeeded: the hybrid format of pre-recorded lectures and in-class examples, provision of practice quizzes
Weaknesses: big class with one room - maybe have students work in smaller groups first, then go over the example at the end of class?
I really liked the flipped classroom setup, and the in-class exercises were useful for completing the homeworks

I wish that all the in-class exercises and homework assignments were available by the beginning of the semester so that I could download them onto my devices and better prepare in advance to complete them.
Though of course everything is better in-person, I thought the course did as well as it could with the virtual format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It's a great introduction to linguistics. There are no tests, only psets and we do examples of each pset which makes them fairly easy. There are also tons of opportunity to get help on psets if you need it. And there's the option of taking a final or writing a paper.
This is a very interesting course that covers the basics of historical linguistics. However, if it is still being taught remotely, I would not recommend it.

I wouldn't strongly recommend it but if you have an interest in linguistics and have taken intro (or other courses) then you might enjoy this. I would not recommend this as a first linguistics class, even though there are technically no prerequisites. You will have a hard time without prior knowledge of phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax, etc.
Yes! Prof Sanker is awesome and the class gets you thinking a lot about language and change
If you are at all interested in either how languages change or phonetics, absolutely!
Yes! Super interesting topics on language change/history
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in linguistics.
Absolutely. I find it very helpful to learn about linguistics no matter your major.
Definitely. I really enjoyed learning the material and the work was manageable. Great class for anyone interested in linguistics.

I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in historical linguistics because I feel like I learned a lot, but I wouldn't recommend to someone who isn't as interested in the subject and wants to fulfil a requirement. There wasn't as much engagement with professor/classmates, and all of my motivation came from my own interest.
I would definitely recommend it. It really is interesting material, and allows you to think in a whole new way.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture one day and seminar style example problems the other day
Recorded lectures
In addition to 2-3 recorded lectures a week, we met once a week in a virtual seminar format to complete an in-class exercise.
Recorded lectures and virtual seminars/discussion section
Pre-recorded lectures and live interactive class once per week
Recorded lecture + group exercise in class time
Virtual discussion about a problem set
Recorded Lectures and in-person lectures for completing examples together
In-person discussion format

Live virtual lecture
Recorded lecture
Live virtual section and recorded lectures.
Also had virtual in-class exercises. Kind of like a "flipped classroom" setup.
We also had weekly mandatory meetings where we completed exercises related to the homework and another optional weekly class period that worked like office hours.
There were recorded lectures and then a virtual live lecture once a week where we worked through an exercise, plus live virtual office hours.
